```{r setup_data, echo=FALSE} 
library(tidyverse)

logged_data <- read_csv("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vRj_FykWQXQDQKpfHbQ1JUJVkplicx5hZpc9LiMdasbcXWafHxtT8oNwaUURpcQGFrE1M83SJxbpKPm/pub?output=csv") 

latest_data <- logged_data %>%
  rename(
    timestamp = Timestamp,
    category = `What category does the ad belong to?`,
    views = `How many times have you seen an ad from this particular business, brand or service during the 5-minute observation period?`,
    sponsor = `Was this ad sponsored by a well-known brand or an independent seller?`,
    relevance = `How relevant is this ad to your interests?`
  )

num_ads <- length(latest_data$views) # We are using the this variable to find the number of views of the ads

min_views <- min(latest_data$views) # We are finding the minimum number of ads in the 5mins period

max_views <- max(latest_data$views) # We are finding the maximum number of ads in the 5mins period

mean_views <- mean(latest_data$views) %>% round(1)# We are using mean_views to calculate the mean number of the views and we are also rounding it to one decimal place.

```


## Insights from My Instagram Ads Data!

The minimum number of views recorded for an ad was `r min_views`, while the maximum was `r max_views`. The average number of views was `r mean_views` across `r num_ads` ads logged.

```{r graph, echo=FALSE} 
latest_data %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_bar(aes(x = category, fill = category)) + 
  labs(title = "Instagram Ads by Category",
       subtitle = "Comparing the distribution between the number of Instagram ads by the different categories",
       caption = "Source: Survey Data",
       x = "Ad Category",
       y = "Number of Ads")

latest_data %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_bar(aes(x = sponsor, fill = sponsor)) + 
  labs(title = "Instagram Ads by Sponsor Type",
       subtitle = "Comparing well-known brands and independent sellers",
       caption = "Source: Survey Data",
       x = "Sponsor Type",
       y = "Number of Ads")
```
